title: 111_hr6501
content: Establishment of Commission. The National Commission on Presidential War Powers and Civil Liberties is established to investigate executive branch national security policies post-9/11, including detention, interrogation techniques, extraordinary rendition, warrantless surveillance, targeted killings, and use of litigation tactics to avoid judicial review. The National Commission on Presidential War Powers and Civil Liberties investigates executive branch national security actions post-9/11, including detention, interrogation techniques, extraordinary rendition, warrantless surveillance, targeted killings, and use of litigation tactics to avoid judicial review. The Commission may also review other relevant policies. The Commission is tasked with investigating relevant facts, circumstances, and laws surrounding activities post-9/11, reporting findings to the President and Congress, and considering other investigations to avoid duplication. It must also operate in a manner consistent with national security needs. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders, with restrictions on political party affiliation and government employment. The Commission should consist of prominent US citizens with expertise in various fields, appointed within 120 days of the Act's enactment. If six or more members are appointed within 60 days, they can hold an initial meeting and select a temporary Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. The Commission, consisting of US citizens with expertise, can select a temporary Chairperson and Vice Chairperson to start operations, including staff hiring. Meetings will be called by the Chairperson or majority members, with five members needed for a quorum. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The President appoints the Chairperson, and the Senate minority leader appoints the Vice Chairperson based on political party affiliation. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson of the Commission cannot be from the same political party. SEC. 4. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and issue subpoenas to compel witnesses to testify and produce relevant documents. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas to compel witnesses to testify and produce documents. Subpoenas can be served nationwide and must be obeyed; refusal may result in a court order to appear before the Commission. The Commission can issue subpoenas to compel witnesses to testify and produce documents. Failure to obey may result in a court order for appearance before the Commission. The court can punish non-compliance as civil contempt. The Commission can issue subpoenas to compel witnesses to testify and produce documents. Failure to comply may result in a court order for appearance before the Commission, with potential punishment for non-compliance as civil contempt. In cases of witness failure to obey, the Commission can certify the matter to the United States attorney for grand jury action. The United States attorney can receive certification under specific statutes. The Commission can hold closed meetings if deemed necessary for national security. It can also enter into contracts and obtain information from federal agencies. The Commission can request information from federal agencies and receive administrative support from the General Services Administration. Other departments and agencies can also provide services, funds, and staff as authorized by law. The Commission may utilize postal services as needed. The Commission may use the United States mails and authorize subcommittees, members, or agents to take actions on its behalf as allowed by law. SEC. 5. STAFF OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. Additional staff may be appointed as needed without following certain civil service laws regarding appointments and pay rates. The Commission may appoint individuals as employees under specific sections of the United States Code. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their regular employment rights. The Commission can also procure consultant services at specified rates. SEC. 6. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES. Members of the Commission may receive compensation at a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also entitled to travel expenses while performing Commission duties. SEC. 7. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. SEC. 7. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. The executive departments and agencies must provide security clearances to Commission members and staff promptly, following existing procedures. Access to classified information is only granted to those eligible for such clearance. The Commission must submit an initial report to the President and Congress within 1 year of its first meeting, followed by a final report within 6 months. The Commission and its authorities will terminate 60 days after the final report is submitted. The Commission may use the 60-day period after submitting its final report to conclude its activities, including providing testimony to Congress and disseminating the second report. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $3,000,000 authorized for the Commission to carry out the Act, available until expended or Commission termination.
